newsitem.title: OMAN: Oman signs upstream contract for gas project.
newsitem.headline: Oman signs upstream contract for gas project.

text.p: Oman on Tuesday signed a $1.4 billion funding deal with foreign partners in its main oil company to develop gas reserves for its liquefied natural gas (LNG) project, the Ministry of National Economy said.
The deal is with Petroleum Development Oman (PDO)'s foreign partners Royal Dutch Shell Group, France's Total SA and independent Partex.
"The funding agreement...requires that the private shareholders (Shell, Total, Partex) shall make available the funds needed for constructing the upstream project," a ministry statement said.
"The Government would pay the investment value to private shareholders as of 2001 through 2006 from the income earned from selling gas and condensate associated with natural gas," it added.
"The investment cost of the upstream project is around $1.4 billion."
PDO, 60 percent owned by the Omani government, will operate the upstream part of the project for 25 years.
Oman is aiming to build a $6 billion LNG project which will begin exports at the turn of the decade.
